Linear Types for Computational Effects Alex Simpson LFCS, School of Informatics, University of Edinburgh 
InformaticsForum,10 Crichton Street, Edinburgh, EH8 9AB, Scotland,UK Alex.Simpson@ed.ac.uk Abstract 
I shall present an extension of Moggi s computational meta­language with primitives from linear logic, 
the enriched effect­calculus. Illustrative applications to side effects, continuations, nondeterminism 
and polymorphism will be considered. The talk is based on joint work with JeffEgger and Rasmus Møgelberg. 
Categories and Subject Descriptors D.3.1[Programming Lan­guages]: Formal De.nitions and Theory; D.3.3 
[Programming Languages]: Language Constructs and Features; F.3.2 [Logics and Meanings of Programs]: Semantics 
of Programming Lan­guages; F.3.3[Logics and Meanings of Programs]: Studies of Program Constructs; F.4.1[Mathematical 
Logic and Formal Lan­guageslogics]: Mathematical Logic General Terms Language, Theory Extended Abstract 
Oneofthe most successful contributionsto program semanticsover the last two decades has been the development 
of a general the­ory of computational effects, encompassing manyof the imperative aspects of computation 
(nontermination, side effects, input/output, exceptions, nondeterminism, probabilistic choice, control 
features, etc.). The crucial insights, both due to Moggi (6; 7), are: (i) that manykindsofeffect canbe 
encapsulated semanticallybythe math­ematical notion of strong monad;and (ii) that a general.-calculus 
for effects, the computational metalanguage, can be based on this. In a 1996 paper (1), Benton and Wadler 
observe that there is considerable overlap between Moggi s computational metalan­guage, and Girard s 
intuitionistic linear logic (3). On the semantic side, models of intuitionistic linear logic always induce 
strong mon­ads on a cartesian-closed category, and so also provide models of Moggi s language. On the 
syntactic side, different translations of typed .-calculus into Moggi s metalanguage (e.g., call-by-name, 
call-by-value) correspond to different interpretations of intuitionis­tic logic in linear logic. However, 
Benton andWadler also observe that there are mis­matches between the two worlds. In particular, the models 
of Moggi s computational metalanguage that arise from models of linear logic are very special ones: their 
strong monads are always commutative. Computationally, commutativity corresponds to ef­fects not being 
affected by their order of invocation. This is a very Copyright is held by the author/owner(s). POPL 
09, January 18 24, 2009, Savannah, Georgia, USA. ACM 978-1-60558-379-2/09/01. severe restriction indeed; 
e.g.,itexcludes sideeffects, input/output, exceptions and control. Accordingly, Benton and Wadler ask 
the natural question of whether it is possible to modify linear logic, retaining much of its expressivity, 
in such a way that an exact cor­respondence with the computational metalanguage is achieved. In this 
talk,Ishall presentavariation on intuitionistic linear logic, the enriched effect-calculus, that enjoys 
such a correspondence. Thus Benton andWadler s questionis answeredin the positive. The principal envisaged 
area of application, for the enriched effect-calculus, is to situations in which there are crucial interac­tions 
between linearity and effects. For example, in computation with side effects, the manipulation of state 
is (usually) linear in the sense that anymodi.cation to the state overwrites the current state, which 
is then non-recoverable (i.e., there is no possibility of snapback ), see (4).A second classofexamplesisgivenby 
the manystructured forms of control that use their continuations in a linearfashion, see(2).Athirdexampleis 
nondeterministic compu­tation, where typically each nondeterministic choice is made once and for all: 
the computation does not subsequently backtrack and explore other choices. Another, surprising, situation 
in which the presence of linear primitives proves useful is in developing a the­ory of relational parametricity 
for polymorphism in combination with computational effects, see (5). The main aim of the talk is to motivate 
and present the enriched effect-calculus through its application to computationally interest­ing examples. 
The focus will be on syntactic and computational aspects, with the categorical model theory being left 
in the back­ground.However,if time permits,Iwill brie.yexplainhowevery model has a dual, and how a generic 
linear continuation-passing transform arises as the unique structure-preserving functor from the free 
model to its dual. References [1] Benton, N. and Wadler, P. Linear Logic, Monads and the Lambda Calculus. 
In Proceedings of 11th Annual IEEE Symposium on Logic in Computer Science, 1996. [2] Berdine, J., O Hearn, 
P.W., Reddy, U. and Thielecke, H. Lin­ear continuation-passing. Higher Order and Symbolic Computation, 
15:181 208, 2002. [3] Girard, J.-Y. Linear logic. Theoretical Computer Science, 50, 101 pp., 1987. [4] 
O Hearn,P.W. and Reynolds, J.C. From Algol to polymorphic linear lambda-calculus. Journalof theACM, 47:167-223, 
2000. [5] Møgelberg, R. and Simpson, A. Relational parametricity for computa­tional effects. In Proceedings 
of 22nd Annual IEEE Symposium on Logic in Computer Science, 2007. [6] Moggi, E. Computational lambda-calculus 
and monads. In Proceedings of 4th Annual IEEE Symposium on Logic in Computer Science, 1989. [7] Moggi, 
E. Notions of computation and monads. Information and Computation, 93:55 92, 1991.
